ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I further developed my laboratory skills as well as how to keep a lab notebook and effectively collaborate with others on an experiment. The course also helped me learn how to use my knowledge to design experiments to answer certain questions.
Better understanding of lab techniques and scientific writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the format was very effective. This year most of the materials were prepped for us ahead of time due to covid but I think it would have been nice to have that element just to have a more realistic experience of how to operate in a lab.

good practical research knowledge

could emphasize more on means of data presentation beyond reports - perhaps abstracts, posters, etc. 

and less focus on model organisms and more on maybe different forms of research (translational, basic, etc.)

Strengths: most of the labs were reasonably timed, some of the labs were kind of fun, professor Monero was flexible when it came to scheduling 

Weaknesses: lab reports were extremely painful to write since the instructions were so unclear, most of the labs were needlessly tedious (ex. counting/typing hundreds of drosophila), office hours were nonexistent, getting help was extremely difficult, it was never clear what was expected of us

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. It's a nice way to get introduced to laboratory practice and further develop your critical thinking skills when it comes to designing experiments yourself.
Yes, good especially for freshman and sophomores entering research

Absolutely not. As much as I liked professor Monero as a person, this is by far the worst class I have taken at Yale. After taking Gen Chem lab, physics lab, biochemistry lab, and orgo lab I really thought that this would be a fun way to improve my lab technique. I was very wrong. Trying to understand what was expected of us in the lab reports was exceptionally difficult. While thorough, the lab report guides provided were EXTREMELY unclear. For example, for the drosophila lab, the lab report guide said that 4 different things were the hypothesis we were testing. If you are reading this, you should avoid taking this class at all costs. Seriously, unless this is legitimately the only class the works with your schedule, do not take it. The one redeeming quality was that the final was fair and pretty fun. Other than that, the rest of the semester was extremely unpleasant. 

TLDR: ABSOLUTELY DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.
